titleStmt.title: M54, 9 of 11. [Anon: The road led to the old graves...]. Typescript fragment, 8 fols.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M54, 9 of 11. [Anon: The road led to the old graves...]. Typescript fragment, 8 fols.

N.B.: This is one of eleven sub-fragments identified in the Berg Collection's M54. [Anon: The printing press brought the past into existence...]. Typescript fragments, unsigned and undated, 35 fols. I have determined pagination and sequencing based on subject matter. M54 as curated by the Berg Collection is available as part of 'The Digital Anon' and can be found at [LINK].

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p:
The road led to the old graves, to the stones where the
old pagan English had offered sacrifice. The peasants still
went that way, in spring (spir ng), summer and winter, by instinct.
The old Gods still (stil) lay hidden beneath the new.
Even if they were now nameless, it was to txxxxx do them
homage, to win crops, husbands, health, that the
peasants came amxmxmxmxmxmxm in spring summer and
winter.

It is the printing press that we owe their
preservation. "After that I had accomplished and finished (finsihed)
divers histories" wrote in 1470 (41470) in the preface
to the , "many noble and divers gentlemen
of this realm of England came and demanded me many and oft
times ..... to imprint the history of the said noble king
and conqueror , and of his knights with the
history of the and of the death and ending of
the said Arthur." The twenty one books of the Morte DArthur
preserve what lay beneath (benea th), there (Ther) we tap into the deep reservoir
of common belief that lay behind the peasant and the noble.
The legend (legnd) was still alive in the nineteenth century.
"...folks do say" said a peasant at that on the
night of the full moon King Arthur (Arthus) and his men ride round
the hill, and their horses are shod with silver..."
A silver horseshoe, says, was found in
time at . It is in pages that we hear the
voice of anon murmuring in the mind of King and Queen and
peasant, They remembered how the old King

and his knights went their ways through the wild woods seek
ing adventure. When himself doubted. Nosuch a man, he
objected, had ever lived. But the nobles were positive,
they said that you could see skull at
and the at and in "in other places
sword and many other things.

The book itself represents scepticism, and the
nobles faith. It is half fable, half fact. There is ,
and and ; there is the
and . But the roads lead past London to
castles where Knights lie in prison; down the roads ride
Queens on white mules; turns suddenly to
stone; and a hand rises from a lake holding .
In the candour (canfdour) with which (wh h) it is told, it is a childs story.
But the the child has lived for centuries. It has not our pers
spective. The inventories, the catalogues are made (mad) with
a childs particularity (partciularity). The clear eye sees definitely and
without exaggeration. Beauty is in the thing itself, not i
in the writers manipulation. So he went in and searched
chamber from chamber to chamber, and found his bed, but she
was not there; then Balin lookedinto a fxmx little garden
and under a laurel tree he saw her lie upon a quilt of
green samite and a knight (kmight) with her, and under their heads
grass and herbs."

But It is not a childs world; it is a world before self
consciousness has raised its (i s) mirror. The men and women are
angular (angualr), gigantic; freed from something (somthing) impure; yet sin
tarnished, acquainted (acqauinted) with sorrow, corrupt, in the midst of
this fresh landscape, remembering,

Of the writer, nothing is known (knonw). He is not [illeg.] emerged
distinct (disnctin c) from his book (hsi ook). It is still the anonymous voice
speaking anonymously (anonysmously) generally that (hat) the listener (lsiener) already
half (hald) knows, or remembers (rmemebers). The listener (lsiener) hears the voice
partly in himself; as it comes from the man at the back
door who has been travelling in strange (trange) parts across (acrsoos) the
marsh across the flood to remind (r mind) the peasant (peasnt) and the noble
of the world that was before them. And still the dream
lingered; for the peasants (peasnts)

In the great house and the cottage this half articulate
voice murmured of old gods and (a d) kings and knights (inihgts)
The well and the tree were still haunted. King Arthur
the foresters (foreste s) said in the thirteenth century (cnetury), ;;;"about
noon or midnight (midngiht) when the moon is full and (sufulland) shining
[we?] often see an array of hunters with dogs and sound of
horns who answer (ins anser) to the enquirers (enwuirers) says
that (yhat) they are of the household (hosuehold) and fellowship of
King Arthur (Art ur)." Along the roads from town to town
from house to house (ouse), came the minstrels (minstresl) the jugglers and
the impudent bardes. While (whil) for those who could read it,
Caxtons book told (tol) the old stories set out in print.
then later (late) the instinct to enact, to impersonate

(hat) they believed imagined came into existence.
Even the King and Queen shared the it, and must have
their actors or minstrels (minstersl) to give (vie) body tongue to this
hidden instinct (insticnt) [illeg.]. The actor (acror) was despised (despied);
did he not make use of his body? and did he not,
feeling himself an outcast (otcast), use the outsiders (outiders) privilege of
irresponsible (irrepsoneible) mockery? But the Kings and Queens tolerated
him, as tolerate (to rate) those who say what we are too proud
to admit. Even the church men had to a re aware that the Gods (Gids)
that he worshipped were (wre) not theirs had to yield (yeild) to him;
or to make use of his gift to If they could they constrained
the actors (c ors) and the dancers (da cers) to (t) put off their leaves (l evea) and (na d) bells
and dress themselves as the sacred figures in a miracle play.
But the churchmen did their best to prevent (prvent) them.

The printing press brought the past into existence.
It also brought into existence, seen against (agoanst) the back
ground (rgound) of the past. And it brough by degrees the individual (indivual)
into existence--the individual (indi idual) who looking back sees himself the man who is separate from his book.
against the background. The individual emerges
at last. He is a chronicler and the [illeg.]His name is ; it is also .
Harrison tells us that he has books; and a mastiff;
and digs in (i) the ground for Roman coins. He tells us that he
has never (nev) been more than forty miles from in .
The individual, still much simplified (sumplified), but sxxxxx no longer
nameless, emerges (emrges). He is losing his ambiguity.
the present is becoming visible. Harrison sees the present
moment (15 ) against the settled orderly past.
The present looks degenerate (degenrate), raw, against that past.

It was at half past two in the (th) afternoon that the
trumpets sounded (dounded) and the flag flew over the Theatre.
The playhouse was open to the sky. A penny or twopence was
the price of a seat. There was no scenery; but the walls
were painted; and the actors were richly dressed, according
to one spectator in the cast off robes of the nobles, sold
by their servants. What other amusement was (as) there in the
afternoon, for the gentlement of the court, txxx of the Inns
of Court, for the numbers of captains and soldiers about
London? Only the amusements that Latimer deplored;
carding, dicing, gaming, following of xmxmxmxmxmx
harlots and drinking. The rivxmxmxmxmx audience came from
the crowded (drowded) festering little streets txxxx round
where the buried smelt so strong. The river was crowded with
wherries ferrying them across: The riverside people depended (depnded)
upon their fares. The flag flew; the trumpets sounded (dsounded); and
audience (audince) crowded into the open playhouse, clustered round the
stage; and heard:

At last the voice speaks from the actual body of one man.
xmxmxmxmxm.And the world (wolrd) became visible. Egypt, Libya;
Persia; Greece. It unrolled itself time; and the armies of great (gr at)
Kings; and plains; and palaces. There is no abstraction any
longer. All is visible tangible, audible. Txmxmxmxmxm
Words (ords) seem to swell and stretch and tumble over themselves (themslves)
in the effort to give body to this vast universe.
They can scarcely contain all they would bring forward.

The spring (sprung) is hindered by your smothering host,
For neither rain can fall upon the earth,
Nor sun reflex his virtuous beams thereon,
The ground is mantled with such multitudes.

Abstractions (Abrtactions) withdraw themselves. Axmxmxxx The Kings and
Emperors stride forth, palpable, coloured, strident. The ae
They are hewn, mob- monstrous, brilliantly painted;
but they movel they speak. They emerge like great moths,
still creased (stillcreased) and damp, shaking their wings in splendid
absurd (aburd) hyperboles and raptures and The great names crash
like cymbals

tell him, xmxmxx thy Lord the Turkish Emperor,
Dread (Dre d) Lord of Afric, Europe (Eruope) and Asia,
Great king and conqueror (conqueor) of Graecia (Greacia),
The ocean, Terrene, and the coal-black sea....

Whose (W se) eyes are brighter than the lamps of Heaven (Haevan),
And speech more pleasant (pl sant) than sweet harmony!
that with thy looks canst clear (clclear) the darkened (datkemed) sky,
And calm the rage of thundering Jupiter...

He is beyond the provinces of plain speech (pseech),
revelling in some untouched garden of untouched blooms;
picking plucking (plaucking) words, and strewing them.
There is no shadow; all is gold and purple (urple).
Yet in the very pitch and height of this extravagance,
xmxmxmxmx he veers,
So poets say my lord.
And (An) tis a pretty toy to be a poet..

So distended with rapture, the tune changes
effectively.

Could he stop, he would cutdeeper. But there is no pause;
no shadow. The pageant (pagenat) [illeg.]. The horses neigh.
Kings and Emperors (Empeors) emerge. Battles are fought. Blood flows.
And all over this multitudinous (multitidionous) splendour broods tragedy (agedy)
xmxmxmmxmxmxxx We forbode. We behold the thing as We [illeg.] there
spectacle. There is the end to come. Meanwhile, let us boast (boas)
and triumph.

Our souls, whose faculties can comprehend
The wondrous architecture of the world,
And measure very wandering planets course
Still climbing after knowledge (knowlede) infinite (infinute),
And always moving as the restless spheres (spe eres),
Well us to wear ourselves, and never rest...

That is the melody (meldy) the marching song of this brave
spectacle (septacle). And yet, as if the poet slipped the noose of his
audiences, relieved (releved) himself of its pressure for one moment,
we hear:
amid the sounding (so nding) brass:

What is beauty, (beautym) saith my sufferings, then?
If all the pens that ever poets held
Had fed the feelings (feelingsx) of their masters' thoughts,
.....
If all these had made one poems period (riod),
And all combined in beauty's (b auty's) worthiness,
Yet should there hover in their restless (estless) heads
one thought, one wxxxxxxx grace, one wonder, at the least,
Which into words no virtue can digest

It is a break; a [illeg.] out of keeping; to be recalled at once
a sign that the dramatist is separate from the anonymous (anony ous) play
maker; There is no little language to put on Kings lips;
so that he cannot as yet amalgamate (amalgamante) naturally
the thought and the action. The audience, the shopkeepers (shopr keeprs)
apprentices ensured (insoored) not reflection (relfection) blood [illeg.], but action,
movement (movemnt). The play is still partly the work of the audience;
of the undifferentiated gluttonous word greedy mass.
It is inspired by the common voice, demanding great names,
simple outlines (outl nes); clamour and victory (virtory) and death; not the single (singe)
subtlety of one soul. Reflection (Refelction) breaks off from
action (ction); there is no [harmonising? harming?] (harml sing) common speech.
